S6.T1.caption: Table 1: E-GPT model performance
S6.T1.table:
Hyper-parameters Precision Recall F1
bs=32,lr=1e-03,hd=64,dl=4,drp=0.1 0.5984 0.6441 0.6204
bs=32,lr=2e-03,hd=64,dl=4,drp=0.1 0.6944 0.7511 0.7216
bs=32,lr=3e-02,hd=64,dl=8,drp=0.3 0.5542 0.5878 0.5705
bs=64,lr=1e-03,hd=64,dl=4,drp=0.1 0.5827 0.6518 0.6153
bs=64,lr=2e-03,hd=64,dl=4,drp=0.3 0.4998 0.5341 0.5163
bs=64,lr=3e-02,hd=64,dl=8,drp=0.3 0.5614 0.5239 0.5420
references: We fine-tuned our E-GPT model by experimenting with various hyperparameters: batch sizes (32, 64), learning rates (1e-03, 2e-03, 3e-02), hidden dimensions (64), the number of decoder layers (4-8), and dropout rates (0.1-0.3). Table 1 presents the model’s optimal performance during testing with a batch size of 32, a learning rate of 2e-03, a hidden dimension of 64, 4 decoder layers, and a dropout rate of 0.1. Under these conditions, the model achieved a precision of 69%, a recall of 75%, and an F1-score of 72%. All experiments were conducted over 100 iterations.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2: Network Density and Structural Balance of users’ connection for each time step

Density 0.5984 0.1541 -0.2757 0.6150 0.4669 -0.4242 0.1753 0.5555 0.1753 0.5555
Triadic Closure 0.5984 0.1541 -0.2757 0.6150 0.4669 -0.4242 0.1753 0.5555 0.1753 0.5555
references:
We experimented with our dataset as described in Section 6.1. This dataset comprises 10-time steps of user data, which includes adjacency matrix, demographic information, post-history, and interactions of the users. We measured Network Density, defined as the ratio of actual connections to possible connections within the network. S6.T3.caption: Table 3: Homophily Effect of different post categories
S6.T3.table:
Assortativity Coefficients for User History
Education Sports Politics Finance Art Travel Health Entertainment
0.5984 0.1541 -0.2757 0.6150 0.4669 -0.4242 0.1753 0.5555
references: Table 3 displays the Assortativity Coefficient calculated with respect to User History data. This coefficient reflects the homophily effect among different post categories, indicating how user history influences the formation of new connections and the tendency of nodes with similar attributes to connect.

S6.T4.caption: Table 4: Homophily Effect of different post categories based on user reactions
S6.T4.table:
Assortativity Coefficients for User Reactions
Education Sports Politics Finance Art Travel Health Entertainment
0.3051 0.2029 0.0525 -0.1379 0.1016 0.7722 0.8255 -0.9297

S6.T5.caption: Table 5: Homophily Effect of different post categories based on user’s comments
S6.T5.table:
Assortativity Coefficients for User’s commenting behavior
Education Sports Politics Finance Art Travel Health Entertainment
0.3051 0.2029 0.0525 -0.1379 0.1016 0.7722 0.8255 -0.9297

S6.T6.caption: Table 6: Homophily Effect of different post categories based on post sharing
S6.T6.table:
Assortativity Coefficients for User’s sharing behavior
Education Sports Politics Finance Art Travel Health Entertainment
0.3051 0.2029 0.0525 -0.1379 0.1016 0.7722 0.8255 -0.9297
references: Similarly, Table 6 shows the assortativity coefficient for user engagement, measuring the tendency of nodes with similar behaviors, such as reacting, sharing, and commenting, to form new connections within the network.

S6.T7.caption: Table 7: Homophily Effect of User Demographic attributes
S6.T7.table:
Assortativity Coefficients for User Demography
